title: Git - Distributed Version Control System (DVCS)
description: Tutorial for commonly used git commands
author: Simon Scholz

children.value:
Git is a commonly used DVCS (distributed version control system), which was introduced by Linus Torvalds.
GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket and others are services, where you can easily create a remote git repository.
On Ubuntu is is fairly easy:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: For Windows you'll have to install the following:
It is good practice to apply a common global Git config:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
git config --global user.name "Simon Scholz"
git config --global user.email opensource.simon@gmail.com

git config --global branch.autosetuprebase always
git config --global pull.rebase true
git config --global rebase.autoStash true
git config --global core.autocrlf input


git config --global gpg.program gpg
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

children.value:
Besides configuring name and email setting up rebase and autoStash is really helpful, since this will stash uncommitted changes when pulling from the remote and then pop the changes once your local commits have been rebased onto the changes from the remote repository.
The GPG configs will verify that your commits are really created by you.

to see all your current Git configs.
To see the config of a repository use
In case you want to make use of SSH for cloning a SSH key needs to be created:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C $USER

# or use rsa in case ed25519 is not available on your system

ssh-keygen -q -t rsa -b 4096 -f ~/.ssh/id_rsa -C $USER

children.value: # or use rsa in case ed25519 is not available on your system
The created public key needs to be configured on the remote origin, e.g., GitHub.
You can show the public key by running

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
git clone {uri-of-your-desired-repo}

e.g.

# ssh
git clone git@github.com:SimonScholz/tutorials.git

# https
git clone https://github.com/SimonScholz/tutorials.git

children.value:
Besides cloning a remote repository, you can also initialize it locally.
And on demand this local Git repository can be pushed to a remote origin.

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: Adding files to the staging area and commit changes
Before files can be commited locally, the desired files have to reside in the staging area.

adds a particular file to the staging area.
But you can also add each and every changed file inside the current folder by using
all changed files of the whole repo will be added.
Once there are the desired files inside the staging area they can be commited:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code: git commit -m "Message, which describes what will be commited"

children.value: "Message, which describes what will be commited"
NOTE: When changes are commited, they only reside in your local git repository.

To remove a certain branch use the following command then:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value:
folder in my home directory, which contains a lot of git repositories.
In order to find all repositories, which have uncommitted changes, I created the following script:

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
props.code:
#!/bin/bash

GIT_DIR=~/git

# ANSI color codes
YELLOW='\033[1;33m'
RED='\033[1;31m'
NC='\033[0m' # No Color

dirty_count=0

# Use mapfile to safely handle repo paths
mapfile -t git_dirs < <(find "$GIT_DIR" -type d -name ".git")

for gitdir in "${git_dirs[@]}"; do
  repo_dir=$(dirname "$gitdir")
  cd "$repo_dir"

  # Check for clean tree
  if [ -n "$(git status --porcelain)" ]; then
    echo -e "${YELLOW}###############################################################################################${NC}"
    echo "Dirty repo: $repo_dir"
    git status -s
    ((dirty_count++))
  fi
done

echo
echo -e "${RED}Total dirty repos: $dirty_count${NC}"

children.value: # Use mapfile to safely handle repo paths
This script will find all git repositories in the
directory and check if they have uncommitted changes.
Show all commits since last git tag

Quite often git tags are used for deployments to production.
In order to get an overview on what is going live it can be convenient to list all commits being done since the last git tag was created.

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

children.value: finds the most recent tag reachable from HEAD
is used to show commits after
The other two lines below is used for formatting and styling

html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html .sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}html.sepia .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-sepia);background: var(--shiki-sepia-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-sepia-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-sepia-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-sepia-text-decoration);}
